repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Rural Poverty Reduction
            Project - Sergipe : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Building on the approach utilized
            successfully under the first phase project, the second phase
            Rural Poverty Reduction Project of Sergipe (RPRP2) supports
            the Government of Sergipe in its efforts to reduce rural
            poverty under its "development with inclusion"
            strategy by: (a) improving access of the rural poor to basic
            socioeconomic infrastructure: (b) raising incomes and
            capital assets through investments in productive activities
            and facilitating linkages between small producers and
            markets; and (c) promoting the cross-sector integration of
            investments in rural areas through strengthened
            participatory planning, decision-making and monitoring at
            the community, municipal and state levels. No indirect
            negative impacts or long-term impacts are anticipated.
            However, short term negative impacts include: Inappropriate
            use of tractors may cause compaction, fragmentation and
            disintegration of the soil; contamination of soil;
            deforestation; contamination of water; disturbance of
            natural habitat; and risk of erosion. The Environmental
            Management Plan (EMP) for the project describes the legal,
            institutional and operational context, requirements and
            procedures for ensuring that environmental issues are
            addressed throughout project implementation.

display_title.display_title:
Brazil - Second Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project - Sergipe : environmental assessment (Vol.
            2) : Manual de operações

0.cdata!:
Brasil - Segunda Fase Projeto de Combate
            a Pobreza Rural do Estado de Sergipe : plano de gestão

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Sergipe Rural Poverty Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Sergipe Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project in Brazil were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned were
            as follows: 1) the differentiation of municipalities and
            resource allocations based on United Nations human
            development index (HDI) makes strategic and practical sense
            but requires commitment to the principal and close
            monitoring; 2) Community-driven development (CDD) is
            evolving from pure demand to tied demand with investments
            consistent with government's poverty
            policies/strategies and HDI-based poverty status; 3) CDD
            mechanisms can improve the quality/targeting of non-project
            resources while leveraging complementary funding and
            intensifying poverty reduction efforts; 4) Political, legal
            and bureaucratic impediments to implementation require
            patient, skilled mitigation by the project supervision team;
            5) Indicative annual budgets for Municipal Councils improve
            planning and build confidence in the program; 6) Systematic
            impact evaluation remains elusive; and 7) CDD can
            effectively target poor rural women.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Rural Poverty Reduction - Sergipe
            - Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Poverty Reduction Project in
            the State of Sergipe, aims at reducing the current high
            levels of rural poverty, by improving access to basic
            social, and economic infrastructure, while supporting as
            well productive activities. Project components will: 1)
            provide grants directly to community associations to finance
            small-scale investments, comprising a broad range of
            subprojects, including infrastructure, social investments,
            small scale agro-processing, and minor irrigation schemes;
            2) finance technical assistance, and training to achieve
            institutional capacity, supported by consulting services,
            and other entities to assist in monitoring, supervision and
            evaluation tasks, including assistance for reforms, and on
            the use of information technology for community
            associations; and, 3) support the overall project
            coordination, monitoring and evaluation, to strengthen the
            effectiveness, and quality of project operations. In
            addition, the component will finance incremental operating
            costs of the State Technical Unit.
